questions.text: An investigator develops a new drug that decreases the number of voltage-gated potassium channels in cardiac muscle cell membranes. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug on the myocardial action potential?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

As voltage-gated K+ channels only open after depolarization during an action potential, they are not prime contributors to resting membrane potential. Inward rectifier K+ channels are the predominant channels open at rest and therefore contribute most to the resting potential.

B) INCORRECT:

Depolarization of myocytes is dependant on the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated Na+ channels. Since voltage-gated K+ channels are closed during depolarization, their decrease would not have an effect.

C) CORRECT:

Repolarization of the cardiac myocyte is dependent on the efflux of K+ from the cell. Once the peak of the action potential (∼ +30 mV) is reached, voltage-gated K+ channels will open, causing the cell membrane potential to repolarize towards the resting potential of K+ (∼ -70 mV to -90 mV). Blockade of voltage-gated K+ channels will therefore delay repolarization.
Image Description:

Resting potential (approx. -90mV) relies primarily on potassium channels (inward-rectifier potassium channels), ensuring a steady potassium efflux (iK1).

Phase 0 (depolarization): Neighboring cells stimulate voltage-gated sodium channels within the cell, causing them to open briefly. This results in a sodium influx (iNa ), and, consequently, the membrane potential increases just beyond 0 mV (overshoot).

Phase 1 (partial repolarization): The brief influx of chloride and efflux of potassium (not shown here) causes membrane potential to decrease.

Phase 2 (plateau): The opening of voltage-gated L-type calcium channels causes an influx of calcium ions (iCa), counteracting the repolarization and keeping the membrane potential at approximately 0mV.

Phase 3 (repolarization): Rapid repolarization occurs via the opening of outward-rectifier potassium channels, resulting in a net efflux of potassium.

Phase 4 (resting potential): A steady efflux of potassium (ik1) occurs until the cell is stimulated again and the process begins again at phase 0.

D) INCORRECT:

Depolarization of myocytes is dependent on the influx of sodium ions through voltage-gated Na+ channels. Thus, a decrease of voltage-gated Na+ channels by medications, such as ivabradine or lidocaine, can delay depolarization of the cell, not decrease voltage-gated K+ channels.

E) INCORRECT:

Repolarization of cardiac myocytes is dependant on the efflux of K+ through K+ channels to re-establish resting potential. Accelerated repolarization would therefore require an increase in K+ channels, not a decrease.

F) INCORRECT:

As voltage-gated K+ channels only open after depolarization during an action potential, they are not prime contributors to resting membrane potential. Inward rectifier K+ channels are the predominant channels open at rest and therefore contribute most to the resting potential.
questions.hint: A decreased number of voltage-gated K+ channels results in a decreased K+ outflow.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness, headache, and vomiting for 40 minutes. He is an amateur chef and his symptoms started 10 minutes after he ingested pufferfish that he had prepared. On arrival, he is lethargic. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 92/64 mm Hg. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is started. The cause of this patient's condition exerts its effect by which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Decrease in cell membrane permeability to sodium ions
Increase in cell membrane permeability to chloride ions
Decrease in cell membrane permeability to calcium ions
Decrease in cell membrane permeability to potassium ions
Increase in cell membrane permeability to calcium ions

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tetrodotoxin blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, thereby inhibiting the propagation of action potential in autonomic, motor, and sensory nerve cells. This inhibition initially causes headache, vomiting, and tingling of the tongue and lips; the condition can then progress to ataxia, generalized weakness, paralysis, and sometimes even respiratory and cardiovascular failure. Treatment is supportive, and mechanical ventilation may be needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Drugs that increase the permeability of the cell membrane to chloride ions are used to treat helminth infections (e.g., ivermectin) and constipation (e.g., lubiprostone). Tetrodotoxin does not target chloride channels.

C) INCORRECT:

Voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channels play an important role in the action potential of cardiomyocytes and arterial smooth muscle cells. Their blocking (e.g., by calcium channel blockers) could result in hypotension, as seen in this patient. However, his other symptoms (headache and altered mental status, vomiting, decreased respirations) would not be expected. Furthermore, tetrodotoxin does not target calcium channels.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in cell membrane permeability to potassium ions is the mechanism of dendrotoxin, which is released, for example, by the mamba snake. Potassium channels are also targeted by some antidiabetic drugs (e.g., sulfonylurea and repaglinide) and antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., amiodarone and sotalol). Tetrodotoxin does not target potassium channels.

E) INCORRECT:

Voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channels play an important role in the action potential of cardiomyocytes and arterial smooth muscle cells. They are activated by antihelminthic drugs (e.g., praziquantel), not by tetrodotoxin.
questions.hint: Ingestion of improperly prepared pufferfish can result in intoxication with tetrodotoxin, a potentially life-threatening toxin, which is found primarily in the fish's ovaries and liver.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the reaction of mutated voltage-gated potassium channel subunits. The mutation alters gating properties by reducing the potassium conductance through these channels, which manifests on ECG with a prolongation of the QT interval. Which of the following labeled phases of the action potential will be most affected by this mutation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A represents the phase leading up to the threshold potential (-50 mV), the all-or-nothing cutoff at which enough current is administered to the cell to begin membrane depolarization. Reaching this potential is contingent upon sufficient neurotransmitter binding to receptors to trigger the opening of Na+ channels and generate a full action potential. It does not involve voltage-gated K+ channels.

B) INCORRECT:

B represents the depolarization phase of the action potential, characterized by a rapid rise in membrane potential. It occurs via the massive influx of Na+ ions through voltage-gated Na+ channels that drive the membrane potential towards the equilibrium potential for Na+ (+60 mV). During this phase, all voltage-gated K+ channels remain closed. Therefore, the properties of the depolarization phase are determined solely by sodium channels, and alterations to voltage-gated K+ channels will have no effect on this phase of the action potential.

C) INCORRECT:

C represents the overshoot phase, the point at which the membrane potential passes neutral (0 mV) and continues to depolarize until the peak action potential is reached (approx. +30 mV). During this period, most Na+ channels are open, but the voltage-gated K+ channels are almost entirely closed. While this mutation, which reduces the voltage-gated K+ channel current, may then have a small effect on the overshoot section due to the few K+ channels that begin to open at this point, it will have a much more profound effect on a different phase of the action potential.

D) CORRECT:

D represents the repolarization phase of the action potential, where the cell is driven back towards the resting default state. This phase is primarily driven by potassium efflux from voltage-gated K+ channels as the voltage-gated Na+channels are now closed. This mutation in the voltage-gated K+ channels alters gating properties so that there is a reduction in the repolarizing K+ current. This decrease in repolarization current will prolong the period of time during which the ventricles are fully depolarized. This manifests as a prolonged QT interval on ECG.
Image Description:

Upper chart: Illustration showing changes in membrane potential over time (during a single action potential). A neuronal cell membrane with a resting potential of approx. -70 mV (teal) depolarizes slowly until it reaches its threshold potential of approx. -50 mV (yellow), at which point it depolarizes abruptly (orange). Depolarization ends with a brief positive polarization of the membrane (overshoot; peak approx. 30 mV; red), after which a rapid repolarization phase begins (green) and the membrane potential becomes negative again. The membrane potential very briefly (for approx. 2 ms) drops below the resting potential (hyperpolarization; approx. -90 mV; blue) before returning to baseline (resting potential; approx. -70 mV; teal).

Lower chart: The changes in membrane potential shown above occur due to changes in membrane ionic conductivity, particularly for sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions. At baseline, membrane conductivity for K+ (purple) is far greater than that for Na+ (blue). This changes abruptly during the depolarization phase, as voltage-dependent Na+ channels open. With some delay, membrane conductivity for potassium also increases as voltage-dependent K+ channels open (while Na+ channels begin closing again). This leads to the repolarization and subsequently hyperpolarization of the membrane.

(Note that the specific values for membrane potentials differ between cell types and that some cell types do not have a stable resting potential.)

E) INCORRECT:

E represents the hyperpolarization phase of the action potential, the point at which membrane potential drives below the resting potential on its return to baseline. It is caused by the continued efflux of some K+ channels after repolarization such that the membrane potential approaches the equilibrium potential of K+ (-90 mV). During this period, Na+ channels are briefly inactivated, preventing a new action potential from being generated. This is known as the refractory period. This mutation will not greatly affect this phase of the action potential because it does not affect the equilibrium potential for K+.

F) INCORRECT:

F represents the return to the default excitable state of the cell, the resting membrane potential, following a full action potential (AP). At this resting voltage, determined by the relative intracellular and extracellular concentrations of Na+ and K+, Voltage-gated K+ and Na+ channels are closed but can be activated again to initiate a new AP. Since this mutation is specific to voltage-gated K+ channels, it will not affect the resting membrane potential.
questions.hint: QT interval prolongation (long QT syndrome) is often a result of a reduction in efflux of potassium from the cell through the voltage-gated K+ channels during the repolarization phase of the action potential.

questions.text:
An investigator is studying the electrophysical properties of gastrointestinal smooth muscle cells using microelectrodes. He measures the resting membrane potential of a cell to be -70 mV. The equilibrium potentials of different ions involved in generating the membrane potential are shown.


ENa+

+65 mV


EK+

-85 mV


ECa2+

+120 mV


EMg2+

+10 mV


ECl-

-85 mV


Which of the following is the most important contributor to maintaining the resting membrane potential at a higher value than the equilibrium potential of potassium?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Since ECa2+ is positive, the influx of Ca2+ would increase the resting membrane potential (RMP). However, the cell membrane of gastrointestinal smooth muscle cells is relatively impermeable to Ca2+ at the RMP, meaning its movement is not a significant contributor to the RMP.

The influx of Ca2+ via L-type voltage-gated channels is responsible for initiating muscle contraction in smooth muscle cells, but only in a depolarized state. These voltage-gated channels do not allow permeability of Ca2+ at RMP.

B) INCORRECT:

Since EMg2+ is positive, an influx of Mg2+ would increase the resting membrane potential (RMP). But the cell membrane is relatively impermeable to Mg2+, meaning its movement is not a significant contributor to the RMP.

C) INCORRECT:

The cell membrane is permeable to chloride ions. But Cl- is negatively charged, meaning an influx of this ion into the cell would cause the resting membrane potential to decrease rather than increase.

D) INCORRECT:

Na+-K+-ATPase moves two K+ ions into the cell for every three Na+ ions that it pumps out of the cell. Na+-K+-ATPase is indirectly responsible for maintaining the resting membrane potential (RMP) by creating K+ and Na+ concentration gradients across the membrane. However, the electrogenic effect of Na+-K+-ATPase, which is due to the movement of more positive ions out of the cell than into the cell, only has a minor contribution to the RMP (approx. -1 to -3 mV). Moreover, the electrogenic effect of Na+-K+-ATPase would drive the RMP to a more negative value bringing the RMP closer to EK+.

E) CORRECT:

The membrane potential is calculated by the Goldman equation and is closest to the equilibrium potential of the ion that has the highest permeability across the membrane. The resting membrane potential (RMP) is the membrane potential when the cell membrane is not undergoing any significant changes in its ion permeability. In all cells, the RMP is closest to EK+ because the membrane is most permeable at rest to K+ ions (via K+ leak channels).

EK+ is, however, not the only contributor to the RMP. K+ leak channels also allow Na+ diffusion along the concentration gradient (Na+ influx). Since the permeability of Na+ through these channels is much less than that of K+, ENa+ only has a minor effect on the cell's RMP but this contribution of the positive value of ENa+ is the primary reason why the RMP (-70 mV) is at a higher value than EK+ (-85 mV).

In cells that are able to undergo depolarization (e.g., nerve, muscle cells), the permeability of the membrane to Na+ and subsequent Na+ influx can be significantly increased by the opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels. The Na+ influx drives the membrane potential in the direction of the ENa+.
questions.hint: The equilibrium potential for an ion (Eion), which is calculated using the Nernst equation, is negative for a predominantly intracellular cation and positive for a predominantly extracellular cation. The membrane potential, which is the difference between the electrical potential of a cell's interior and its exterior, is primarily determined by the relative permeability of the cell membrane to different ions and their respective equilibrium potentials.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for progressive bilateral lower extremity weakness and absent deep tendon reflexes. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an elevated protein concentration and a normal cell count. Treatment with plasmapheresis is initiated, after which her symptoms start to improve. Four weeks after her initial presentation, physical examination shows normal muscle strength in the bilateral lower extremities and 2+ deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following changes in neuronal properties is the most likely explanation for the improvement in her neurological examination?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Recovery from GBS involves remyelination of the demyelinated nerve segments. Remyelinated nerves have an increased transmembrane resistance compared to demyelinated nerves because the myelin sheath functions as an electrical insulator, thereby permitting the electrical action potentials in myelinated nerves to travel further before decaying. This increased resistance produces an increase in length constant.

Other factors that increase the length constant include decreased axonal resistance and increased axonal diameter.

B) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction velocity is most significantly impacted by the presence or absence of myelin on a given nerve. In the presence of myelin, saltatory conduction is possible and nerve conduction velocities are much higher than in nerves that lack myelin sheaths. In patients with GBS, nerve conduction velocity is much slower as a result of significant demyelination. The recovery process involves restoration of the myelin sheath so nerve conduction velocities would be expected to increase.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased transmembrane resistance results from demyelination of nerve fibers, which accounts for the symptoms observed in this patient with GBS. The results of this patient's neurological examination four weeks after her initial presentation are significantly improved, indicating that the nerves have undergone remyelination. Transmembrane resistance increases as a result of remyelination.

D) INCORRECT:

Recovery from GBS involves the restoration of the normal myelin sheath surrounding the axons of peripheral nerves. The presence of myelin increases nerve cell membrane resistance because it is an electrical insulator. Resistance is inversely proportional to capacitance. Therefore, the axonal capacitance is likely to be reduced in the recovery phase of GBS.

E) INCORRECT:

Axial resistance refers to the intrinsic quality of a given axon and it derives from the specific cytoplasmic makeup of a neuron and the cross-sectional area of cytoplasm. Axons with a larger cross-sectional area as well as those with increased cytoplasm conductivity are able to facilitate greater ion transfer and, therefore, have lower axial resistance. Neither the pathophysiology of GBS or the recovery process affects the diameter or cytoplasmic content of an axon so a change in axial resistance would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

GBS has been associated with near normal or slightly decreased action potential amplitude. Therefore, action potential amplitude would be expected to remain constant or increase slightly in this recovered patient.
questions.hint: Increased cerebrospinal protein content with normal cell count (e.g., cytoalbuminologic dissociation) in the context of progressive lower extremity weakness and areflexia is consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman has an 8-month history of gradually progressive, symmetrical numbness and weakness in her feet and hands. A sural nerve biopsy demonstrates segmental loss of myelin sheaths. Which of the following processes is most directly impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Action potential propagation via saltatory conduction
Action potential generation at the axon hillock
Neurotransmitter reuptake at the presynaptic membrane
Neurotransmitter release at the synaptic cleft

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myelin sheaths are formed around the axon by oligodendrocytes in the CNS and Schwann cells in the PNS. Myelin sheaths enable the rapid propagation of action potentials via saltatory conduction, allowing electrical impulses to jump between nodes of Ranvier and propagate much more quickly than in non-myelinated nerve fibers. The thicker the myelin sheath, the faster the conduction of the stimulus. Myelinated nerve fibers are present in the white matter tracts of the CNS and type A and B nerve fibers of the PNS. Demyelinating diseases of the CNS (e.g., multiple sclerosis) and PNS (e.g., Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy) disrupt saltatory conduction, leading to slowed or blocked transmission of nerve impulses.

Key learning point: Myelin increases conduction velocity via saltatory conduction at the nodes of Ranvier.
Image Description:

Continuous conduction (top left) occurs in non-myelinated nerve fibers. Action potentials migrate along the entire cell membrane, as depolarization of one section initiates depolarization of the next and the refractory period prevents backpropagation.

Saltatory conduction (bottom left) occurs in myelinated nerve fibers. These have intermittent gaps in the insulating myelin layer, called nodes of Ranvier. Action potentials skip along the cell membrane, as depolarization in one node initiates depolarization of the next, resulting in higher conduction velocities than possible through continuous conduction.

Conduction velocity (right) is increased by myelination (saltatory conduction) and increasing nerve fiber diameter.

B) INCORRECT:

An action potential is generated at the axon hillock when summated excitatory and inhibitory potentials received via the dendrites exceed the threshold potential for depolarization. Demyelination affects a process that occurs distal to the axon hillock.

C) INCORRECT:

Neurotransmitter reuptake at the presynaptic membrane is typically facilitated by secondary active symporters that harness the electrochemical gradients established by the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. In the CNS, these symporters can be inhibited by certain antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs) or recreational substances (e.g., cocaine). Demyelination affects a different part of the neuron.

D) INCORRECT:

Neurotransmitter synthesis occurs in the neuron's cell body. It can be affected by factors such as a deficiency of precursors (e.g., amino acids) or a defect in enzymes responsible for neurotransmitter synthesis (e.g., due to vitamin cofactor deficiencies). Demyelination affects a part of the neuron that does not contain Nissl granules.

E) INCORRECT:

Exocytosis of neurotransmitters at the synaptic cleft can be inhibited by factors that prevent vesicle fusion with the presynaptic membrane, such as impaired synaptobrevin cleavage (due to tetanus or botulinum toxins), low extracellular calcium levels, or destruction of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (e.g., in Lambert-Eaton syndrome). Demyelination affects a different aspect of neural function.
questions.hint: This process cannot occur in type C nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and certain interneurons in the gray matter of the central nervous system (CNS).
